title: Oreanda
text:
Oreanda (<a href="Ukrainian%20language">Ukrainian</a> and <a href="Russian%20language">Russian</a>: Ореанда; ) is an <a href="urban-type%20settlement">urban-type settlement</a> in the <a href="Yalta%20Municipality">Yalta Municipality</a> of the <a href="Autonomous%20Republic%20of%20Crimea">Autonomous Republic of Crimea</a>, a territory recognized by a majority of countries as part of <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> and <a href="Annexation%20of%20Crimea%20by%20the%20Russian%20Federation">annexed</a> by <a href="Russia">Russia</a> as the <a href="Republic%20of%20Crimea">Republic of Crimea</a>.
Oreanda is administratively subordinate to the <a href="Livadiya%2C%20Crimea">Livadiya</a> Settlement Council. The urban-type settlement's population was 887 as of the <a href="Ukrainian%20Census%20%282001%29">2001 Ukrainian census</a>. Current population: 
Geography.
Oreanda is located on Crimea's southern shore at an elevation of . The settlement is located from <a href="Yalta">Yalta</a>. The Khrestova peak of the <a href="Crimean%20Mountains">Crimean Mountains</a> is located in Oreanda.
History.
Oreanda was first mentioned in <a href="Peter%20Simon%20Pallas">Peter Simon Pallas</a>'s 1793 book "Journey through various provinces of the Russian Empire" as Urhenda (<a href="Cyrillic%20alphabet">Cyrillic</a>: Ургенда).
In the first half of the 19th century, Oreanda belonged to the <a href="House%20of%20Potocki">House of Potocki</a>; it later became a part of the Russian <a href="tsar">tsar</a>'s territory. From 1842-1852, a <a href="Greek%20Revival%20architecture">Greek Revival</a> palace was built in Oreanda by architect <a href="Andrei%20Stackenschneider">Andrei Stackenschneider</a>. The <a href="United%20States">American</a> writer <a href="Mark%20Twain">Mark Twain</a> once stayed at the palace before it burned down in 1882. <a href="Leonid%20Brezhnev">Leonid Brezhnev</a> had a house in Oreanda which President <a href="Richard%20Nixon">Richard Nixon</a> visited in 1974 following the <a href="Moscow%20Summit%20%281974%29">Moscow Summit</a>. 
In the 1940s-1950s, two <a href="sanatorium">sanatorium</a>s were built in Oreanda, one of which was designed by <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet</a> <a href="Constructivist%20architecture">Constructivist</a> architect <a href="Moisei%20Ginzburg">Moisei Ginzburg</a>.
In culture.
Much of <a href="Anton%20Chekhov">Anton Chekhov</a>'s short story "<a href="The%20Lady%20with%20the%20Dog">The Lady with the Dog</a>", published in 1899, takes place in Oreanda.
